title: Classic Jingles & Slogans
description: Can you match these iconic advertising jingles and slogans to the right brand? Test your memory of vintage commercials!

questions.question: Which brand used the slogan 'The pause that refreshes'?
questions.explanation: Coca-Cola introduced 'The pause that refreshes' in 1929, and it became one of the most famous slogans in advertising history.

questions.question: Complete the jingle: 'Plop, plop, fizz, fizz, oh what a relief it is!' Which product was this?
questions.explanation: Alka-Seltzer's catchy jingle debuted in 1976 and became one of the most memorable in TV advertising history.

questions.question: 'Where's the beef?' became a national catchphrase thanks to a 1984 commercial for which fast food chain?
questions.explanation: Actress Clara Peller made 'Where's the beef?' famous in Wendy's 1984 commercial. It even became a political catchphrase that year.

questions.question: Which cigarette brand used the slogan 'You've come a long way, baby'?
questions.explanation: Virginia Slims targeted women with this slogan starting in 1968, tying the brand to the women's liberation movement of the era.

questions.question: 'Snap! Crackle! Pop!' has been the slogan for which breakfast cereal since 1932?
questions.explanation: Kellogg's Rice Krispies has used Snap, Crackle, and Pop as mascots since the 1930s, describing the sounds the cereal makes in milk.

questions.question: Which brand told you to 'Let your fingers do the walking'?
questions.explanation: The Yellow Pages used this slogan from the 1960s onward, encouraging people to use the phone directory instead of going store to store.

questions.question: 'I'd like to buy the world a Coke' was featured in a famous 1971 commercial set on an Italian hilltop. What was the full slogan?
options: Have a Coke and a Smile
questions.explanation: The 'Hilltop' commercial featured the song 'I'd Like to Buy the World a Coke' and was part of the 'It's the Real Thing' campaign in 1971.

questions.question: Which cereal mascot declared 'They're Gr-r-reat!'?
questions.explanation: Tony the Tiger has been the mascot for Kellogg's Frosted Flakes since 1952, and his enthusiastic 'They're Gr-r-reat!' is one of advertising's most recognized catchphrases.

questions.question: 'A diamond is forever' is a slogan from which company, first used in 1947?
questions.explanation: De Beers' slogan 'A Diamond is Forever' was created in 1947 and was named the #1 slogan of the 20th century by Advertising Age.

questions.question: 'I can't believe I ate the whole thing!' was a famous line from commercials for which product?
questions.explanation: This classic Alka-Seltzer commercial from 1972 featured a man groaning in bed after overeating, with his wife unsympathetically repeating the line.

questions.question: Which brand promised 'Good to the last drop'?
questions.explanation: Maxwell House has used 'Good to the Last Drop' since 1917. Legend has it that Theodore Roosevelt coined the phrase, though this is debated.

questions.question: 'You deserve a break today' was the jingle for which fast food restaurant starting in 1971?
questions.explanation: McDonald's 'You Deserve a Break Today' campaign launched in 1971 and helped establish the chain as a family-friendly dining destination.

questions.question: Which battery brand featured a pink bunny that 'keeps going and going and going'?
questions.explanation: The Energizer Bunny first appeared in 1989 and became one of the most recognizable advertising mascots. The 'keeps going' slogan became part of pop culture.

questions.question: 'Betcha can't eat just one' was the slogan for which snack brand?
questions.explanation: Lay's potato chips used 'Betcha can't eat just one' starting in 1963, with celebrity endorser Bert Lahr. It cleverly acknowledged the addictive nature of chips.

questions.question: Which soap brand claimed it was '99 and 44/100% pure'?
questions.explanation: Ivory soap has used this unusual purity claim since 1882. It was also famous for floating in water, which Procter & Gamble discovered by accident.

questions.question: 'Look, Ma, no cavities!' was associated with which toothpaste brand?
questions.explanation: Crest toothpaste used 'Look, Ma, no cavities!' starting in 1958 after receiving the American Dental Association's seal of approval.

questions.question: Which brand used the slogan 'Fly the friendly skies'?
questions.explanation: United Airlines introduced 'Fly the Friendly Skies' in 1965. The slogan evoked the glamour and excitement of air travel during its golden age.

questions.question: 'Have it your way' was the slogan for which fast food chain starting in 1974?
questions.explanation: Burger King's 'Have It Your Way' campaign emphasized custom orders, differentiating them from McDonald's more standardized approach.

questions.question: Which car company used the slogan 'See the USA in your ___'?
questions.explanation: Dinah Shore popularized 'See the USA in your Chevrolet' starting in the 1950s on her TV show. It became one of the most beloved automotive jingles.

questions.question: 'Mikey likes it!' became a famous catchphrase from a 1972 commercial for which cereal?
questions.explanation: The Life cereal 'Mikey' commercial showed two brothers getting their picky little brother to try the cereal. It ran for over a decade and became a cultural touchstone.
